overview: If you generate your own electricity (eg with solar panels or a wind turbine) your energy supplier might pay you money for this via a 'Feed-in Tariff' - how to apply, rates, Feed-in Tariff review
title: Feed-in Tariffs: get money for generating your own electricity

table.body:
If you generate your own electricity (eg with solar panels or a wind turbine) your energy supplier might pay you money. This is called a 'Feed-in Tariff'. 

##How the tariffs work

You'll get a set amount for each unit (kilowatt hour) of electricity you generate. The rates vary depending on:

- the size of your system
- what technology you install
- when your technology was installed
- who put the technology in place - you need to use a [certified installer](http://www.microgenerationcertification.org/installers "certified installer"){:rel="external"}

Contact your electricity supplier for more information.

##The export tariff - selling surplus energy 

If you produce more energy than you use, you can sell it back to your electricity supplier. This is called an 'export tariff'. 

Your supplier will pay you 3.1p for every unit of spare electricity, and this money is on top of the Feed-in Tariff - ask your supplier for more information. You can use the calculators below to estimate how much you could earn.

##How much you could get

The Energy Saving Trust has online calculators that help you estimate how much you could earn using the Feed-in Tariff scheme and selling surplus energy back. 

Use the:

- [solar energy calculator](http://www.energysavingtrust.org.uk/Generate-your-own-energy/Solar-panels-PV/Solar-Energy-Calculator "solar energy calculator"){:rel="external"} if you have solar panels
- or the [cashback calculator](http://www.energysavingtrust.org.uk/Generate-your-own-energy/Financial-incentives/Cashback-Calculator "cashback calculator"){:rel="external"} if you have wind turbines, hydroelectricity or micro combined heat and power systems

The Feed-in Tariff is currently [under review](feedin-tariff-review "under review") and the rates are changing - the calculators take this into account.
table.title: Overview

table.body:
Although the Feed-in Tariffs are [under review](feedin-tariff-review "under review"), you can still apply.

To qualify, your installation must have a peak output of no more than 5 megawatts peak output. Technologies covered are:

- solar panels
- wind turbines
- water turbines
- anaerobic digestion (biogas energy)
- micro combined heat and power

Before you apply, do a [home energy check](http://www.energysavingtrust.org.uk/In-your-home/Home-Energy-Check "home energy check"){:rel="external"} to make sure your home is as energy efficient as possible.

Then follow these steps:

s1. Decide which technology is right for your property. 
s2. Get it installed by a [certified installer.](http://www.microgenerationcertification.org/installers "certified installer"){:rel="external"}
s3. Get a Feed-in Tariff qualification certificate from your installer.
s4. Send a copy of the certificate to your energy supplier - they'll check it and let you know if you qualify.
s5. If you qualify, your supplier will register you and send you a confirmation.
s6. You agree with your supplier how often they will pay you (eg monthly, quarterly).
table.title: How to apply

table.body:
The Feed-in Tariff scheme is currently under review. The review is looking at all aspects of the scheme, including:

- the amount you could be paid
- eligible technologies
- how the export tariffs work

If you're already registered with the scheme, the changes won't affect you. 

There's more [information about the review](http://www.decc.gov.uk/en/content/cms/meeting_energy/renewable_ener/feedin_tariff/fits_review/fits_review.aspx "information about the review"){:rel="external"} on the Department of Climate and Energy Change (DECC) website.

*[DECC]:Department of Energy and Climate Change
